revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=January 2012}} {{Culture of Bangladesh}} This is a '''list of [[festivals]] in [[Bangladesh]]'''.
==Religious observance== [[File:Eid Prayers at Barashalghar, Debidwar, Comilla.jpg|thumb|right| Eid prayer in [[Comilla]]]] [[File:Durga puja in Dhakeshwari temple.jpg|thumb|right|[[Durga puja]] in [[Dhakeshwari Temple]], [[Dhaka]]]]
===Muslim=== * [[Eid ul-Fitr]] - on the 1st day of [[Shawwal]] month of the lunar [[Islamic calendar]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/07/19/eid-ul-fitr-celebrated-in-bangladesh|title=Eid-ul-Fitr celebrated in Bangladesh|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Eid ul-Adha]] - on the 10th day of [[Dhu al-Hijjah]] month of the Islamic calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-15615459|title=Eid ul-Adha helps Bangladesh farmers - BBC News|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Chaand Raat]] - on the 29th or 30th night of [[Ramadan]] month of the Islamic calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/shout/chaand-raat-old-dhaka-112417|title=Chaand Raat in Old Dhaka|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Day of Ashura|Ashura]] - on the 10th day of [[Muharram]] in the Islamic calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/oct/14/holy-ashura-oct-24|title=Holy Ashura on Oct 24|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Eid-e-Meeladun Nabi]] – The Birth of the Prophet<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/world/bangladesh-forces-arrest-7-militants-during-raid-on-jmb-hideout/story-vKGtVuDohOM415xCfZjAOO.html|title=Bangladesh forces arrest 7 militants during raid on JMB hideout|website=hindustantimes.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Laylat al-Qadr|Shab-e-Qadr]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/07/20/dhaka-yet-to-get-over-eid-hangover-despite-end-of-holidays|title=Dhaka yet to get over Eid hangover despite end of holidays|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Mid-Sha'ban|Shab-e-Baraat]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/ls-pick/try-old-town-bakeries-shab-e-barat-90376|title=Try old town bakeries this Shab-e-Barat|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Bishwa Ijtema]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/bangladesh/12088120/What-is-the-festival-of-Bishwa-Ijtema-and-where-is-it-held.html|title=What is the festival of Bishwa Ijtema and where is it held?|website=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
===Hindu=== * [[Durga Puja]] - from the 2nd to the 7th day of Kartik month of the [[Bengali calendar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/10/05/durga-puja-public-holiday-on-oct-22|title=Durga Puja public holiday on Oct 21|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Krishna Janmashtami]] - celebration of the birth of the Hindu deity Krishna<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/sep/05/janmashtami-being-observed|title=Janmashtami being celebrated|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Dolyatra]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ebanglapedia.com/en/article.php?id=1716#.Vu0FnfkrLIU|title=Dolyatra|last=Rahman|first=Aunik|website=www.ebanglapedia.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Rathayatra]], the most popular being [[Dhamrai Rathayatra]].<ref name=":0"/> * [[Kali Puja]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/op-ed/2015/nov/26/kali-puja-time-diwali|title=Kali Puja in the time of Diwali|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Saraswati Puja]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2016/feb/13/saraswati-puja-celebration-across-country|title=Saraswati Puja celebration across the country|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
===Buddhist=== * [[Buddha Purnima]] - Buddha's Birthday<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/op-ed/politics/tolerance-bangladesh-787171|title=Tolerance in Bangladesh|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Madhu Purnima]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Madhu_Purnima|title=Madhu Purnima - Banglapedia|website=en.banglapedia.org|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Kathin Chibardan]] - offering of woven robe made of cotton to monks and nuns.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bssnews.net/newsDetails.php?cat=0&id=529638&date=2015-11-03|title=News Details|website=www.bssnews.net|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
===Christian=== * [[Boro Din]] or Christmas - on 25 December of the [[Gregorian calendar]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Christmas-among-banana-trees-and-under-bamboo-stars-23528.html|title=BANGLADESH Christmas among banana trees and under bamboo stars|last=AsiaNews.it|website=www.asianews.it|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Easter Sunday]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2007/04/08/christians-observe-easter-sunday|title=Christians observe Easter Sunday|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
==Patriotic and National Observances== * [[Language Movement Day]] - ([[International Mother Language Day]]); Wearing colour: {{colorbox|white|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|Black|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2016/02/21/bangladesh-pays-tribute-to-language-movement-martyrs|title=Bangladesh pays tribute to Language Movement martyrs|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Bengali Genocide Remembrance Day|Genocide Remembrance Day]] * [[Independence Day (Bangladesh)|Independence Day]]; Wearing colour: {{colorbox|green|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|red|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|gold|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/5-militants-held-in-bangladesh-authorities-suspect-they-had-planned-attacks-on-the-countrys-independence-day-2674014.html|title=5 militants held in Bangladesh, authorities suspect they had planned attacks on the country's Independence Day - Firstpost|website=Firstpost|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Armed Forces Day (Bangladesh)|Armed Forces Day]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2015/nov/21/armed-forces-day-being-marked|title=Armed Forces Day being marked|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Martyred Intellectuals Day]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-martyred-intellectuals-day-observed-in-bangladesh-2155507|title=Martyred Intellectuals Day observed in Bangladesh|website=dna|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Victory Day of Bangladesh|Victory Day]]; Wearing colour: {{colorbox|green|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|red|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|gold|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2015/12/17/victory-day-celebrated-in-bangladesh-with-renewed-joy|title=Victory Day celebrated in Bangladesh with ‘renewed joy’|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
==Cultural festivals== [[File:Pohela boishakh 2.jpg|thumb|right|Celebrations of Pahela Baishakh at Dhaka]] [[File:Bangladeshi girls taking Selfie at Pohela Falgun.jpg|thumb|Bangladeshi girls taking Selfie at Pahela Falgun festival.]]
===General=== * [[Rokeya Day]] * [[Rabindra Jayanti]] * [[Nazrul Jayanti]]
===Music=== * [[Dhaka World Music Festival]] (music)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-172943|title=A World of Music Descends on Dhaka|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Bengal Classical Music Festival]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/news-detail-222545|title=Bengal ITC SRA Classical Music Fest ends on a high note|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
===Folk=== * [[Pahela Baishakh]] - on the 1st day of the Bengali calendar and summer festival; Wearing colour:{{colorbox|white|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|red|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/ushering-in-noboborsho-in-a-thousand-voices-20153|title=Ushering in Noboborsho in a thousand voices|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Basanta Utsab]] - Spring festival; Wearing colour:{{colorbox|yellow|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|red|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2016/feb/13/pahela-falgun-being-celebrated|title=Pohela Falgun being celebrated|website=www.dhakatribune.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Nabanna]] - Winter and harvest festival; Wearing colour:{{colorbox|yellow|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|green|border=darkgray}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/arts-entertainment/event/nobanno-celebrations-chittagong-172822|title=Nobanno celebrations in Chittagong|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Barsha Utsab|Barsha Mangal]] - Monsoon festival; Wearing colour:{{colorbox|white|border=darkgray}} {{colorbox|blue|border=darkgray}}
===Others=== * [[Dhaka Art Summit]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/abinlot/2016/02/22/the-dhaka-art-summit-gives-bangladesh-a-global-spotlight/#237356692f4e|title=The Dhaka Art Summit Gives Bangladesh A Global Spotlight|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Hay Festival Dhaka]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/hay-festival-to-begin-november-20-49526|title=Hay Festival to begin November 20|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Dhaka Fashion Week]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/dhaka-fashion-week-2011-photos-707255|title=Dhaka Fashion Week 2011 (PHOTOS)|website=International Business Times|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Dhaka International Film Festival]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/entertainment/2016/01/15/dhaka-international-film-festival-begins|title=Dhaka International Film Festival begins|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Chobi Mela International Photography Festival]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tehelka.com/2016/02/capturing-the-essence-of-resistance/|title=Capturing the essence of resistance|website=Tehelka - Investigations, Latest News, Politics, Analysis, Blogs, Culture, Photos, Videos, Podcasts|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref>
== Fairs == [[File:Ekushey Book Fair Dhaka Bangladesh 02.JPG|thumb|right|Ekushey Book Fair in Dhaka]] * [[Ekushey Boi Mela|Ekushey Book Fair]] - in Dhaka on the month of February of the Gregorian calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2016/02/29/hundreds-of-thousands-throng-ekushey-book-fair-at-the-end|title=Hundreds of thousands throng Ekushey Book Fair at the end|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Dhaka International Trade Fair]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/business/2016/01/01/pm-inaugurates-dhaka-international-trade-fair-2016|title=PM inaugurates Dhaka International Trade Fair 2016|website=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[National Tree Fair]] - Month-long National Tree Plantation Campaign and Tree Fair.
==Local events== [[File:Kite festival at Shakrain.JPG|thumb|right|Shakrain kite festival, Dhaka]] * [[Shakrain]] - in Dhaka at the end of the [[Poush]] of the Bengali calendar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ryot.org/denizen-video-celebrating-the-shakrain-festival-in-bangladesh/948421|title=The Shakrain Festival in Bangladesh|website=RYOT News|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Jatiya Pitha Utsab]] - National [[Pitha]] (Cake) Festival.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/media-en/image/2014/01/25/jatiya-pitha-utsab|title=Jatiya Pitha Utsab|publisher=bdnews24.com|accessdate= 25 January 2014}}</ref> * [[Joy Bangla Concert]] - annual concert to mark the 7th March Speech of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib. * [[Nouka Baich]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/star-weekend/shutterstories/boats-and-paddlesz-137254|title=Of boats and paddles|website=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> * [[Bisu Mela]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newagebd.net/111619/all-set-to-welcome-bangla-new-year/|title=All set to welcome Bangla New Year - New Age|website=New Age|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-03-19}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Public holidays== * [[Public holidays in Bangladesh]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

page.title: Member states of the Commonwealth of Nations

revision.comment: Irish government did not accept it was in the Commonwealth in 1949
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=July 2015}} [[File:Commonwealth of Nations.svg|thumb|right|350px|Current Commonwealth members (dark blue), former members (orange), and [[British Overseas Territories]] and Crown Dependencies (light blue)]] The [[Commonwealth of Nations]] is a [[voluntary association]] of 53 sovereign states. Nearly all of them are former [[British colony|British colonies]] or dependencies of those colonies. No one government in the Commonwealth exercises power over the others, as is the case in a [[political union]]. Rather, the Commonwealth is an [[international organization|international organisation]] in which countries with diverse social, political, and economic backgrounds are regarded as equal in status, and cooperate within a framework of common values and goals, as outlined in the [[Singapore Declaration]] issued in 1971.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/FAQs/20706/faqs|title=FAQs|accessdate=16 June 2008|publisher=[[Commonwealth Secretariat]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514162902/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/FAQs/20706/faqs/|archivedate=14 May 2008|df=}} Such common values and goals include the promotion of [[democracy]], [[human rights]], [[good governance]], the [[rule of law]], [[individual liberty]], [[egalitarianism]], [[free trade]], [[multilateralism]], and [[world peace]], which are promoted through multilateral projects and meetings, such as the [[Commonwealth Games]], held once every four years.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/20723/32987/singapore_declaration_of_commonwealth_principles|title=Singapore Declaration of Commonwealth Principles 1971|accessdate=12 June 2008|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511174313/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/20723/32987/singapore_declaration_of_commonwealth_principles/|archivedate=11 May 2008|df=}} The symbol of this free association is [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], who serves as the [[Head of the Commonwealth]]. This position, however, does not imbue her with any political or executive power over any Commonwealth member states; the position is purely symbolic, and it is the [[Commonwealth Secretary-General]] who is the chief executive of the Commonwealth.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/150757/head_of_the_commonwealth |title=Head of the Commonwealth |accessdate=16 June 2008 |publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930063803/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/150757/head_of_the_commonwealth/ |archivedate=30 September 2006 |df= }} The Commonwealth was first officially formed in 1931 when the [[Statute of Westminster 1931|Statute of Westminster]] gave legal recognition to the sovereignty of dominions. Known as the "British Commonwealth", the original members were the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]], [[Dominion of New Zealand|New Zealand]], [[Union of South Africa|South Africa]], [[Irish Free State]], and [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], although Australia and New Zealand did not adopt the statute until 1942 and 1947 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealth-of-nations.org/article.php?&id=4&subsection=3&page=3|title=The Commonwealth–History–Dominion Status|accessdate=16 June 2008|publisher=Commonwealth of Nations}} In 1949, the [[London Declaration]] was signed and marked the birth of the modern Commonwealth and the adoption of its present name.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/34493/38150/modern_commonwealth|title=The Commonwealth–History–Modern Commonwealth|accessdate=16 June 2008|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511161917/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/34493/38150/modern_commonwealth/|archivedate=11 May 2008|df=}} The newest member is [[Rwanda]], which joined on 29 November 2009.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/29/world/africa/29rwanda.html|title=Rwanda Joins British Commonwealth|author=Josh Kron|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=29 November 2009|accessdate=29 November 2009}} The most recent departure was the [[Maldives]], which severed its connection with the Commonwealth on 13 October 2016. As of April 2017, of the states that are members of the Commonwealth of Nations, three are in [[Europe]], twelve in [[North America]] and the [[Caribbean]], one in [[South America]], nineteen in [[Africa]], seven in [[Asia]], and eleven in [[Oceania]]. There are seven former members, four of which no longer exist as independent entities (but form part of current member states). The members have a combined population of 2.4 billion, almost a third of the world population, of whom 1.21 billion live in India, and 95% live in Asia and Africa combined.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2119rank.html|title=Country Comparisons – Population|accessdate=22 March 2009|date=19 March 2009|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]}} Currently sixteen of the member states are [[Commonwealth realm]]s, with the [[Head of the Commonwealth]] as their head of state. Five others are [[monarchy|monarchies]] with their own individual monarchs ([[Brunei]], [[Eswatini]], [[Lesotho]], [[Malaysia]], [[Tonga]]) and the rest are republics. [[Republic of Ireland]] (from 1949 according to the Commonwealth; 1936 according to Irish government), [[Zimbabwe]] (2003), and [[Maldives]] (2016) are former members of the Commonwealth. [[South Africa]], [[Pakistan]] and [[The Gambia]] left and later rejoined the Commonwealth. {{Clear}} == Current members == All dates below are provided by the Commonwealth of Nations Secretariat members list, and population figures are as of 1 January 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Internal/142227/members|title=Members|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008}} {| class="wikitable sortable" ! width = 150px|Country ! width = 125px|Joined ! width = 90px|Continent ! width = 80px|Population{{Cite web|url=http://countrymeters.info/en/|title=World population - Countrymeters|access-date=6 March 2018}} ! width = 450px|Notes{{ref|1|[A]}} |- | {{sort|Antigua and Barbuda|{{flagicon|Antigua and Barbuda}} [[Antigua and Barbuda]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1981-11-011 November 1981 | Caribbean | align="right" |94,195 | |- | {{sort|Australia|{{flagicon|Australia}} [[Australia]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | Oceania | align="right" |24,772,247 | Granted nominal independence ([[British Dominions|Dominion]] status) on 1 January 1901. Australia was one of the original Dominions at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]], although the statute was not adopted in Australia until [[Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942|1942]] (with retroactive effect from 1939).{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Templates/YearbookHomeInternal.asp?NodeID=138122|title=Australia|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=2008-02-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214114035/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/Templates/YearbookHomeInternal.asp?NodeID=138122|archivedate=2008-02-14|df=}} The ''[[Australia Act 1986]]'' established specifically, only the State Premier could now advise the Queen on appointment or removal of a State Governor. Nonetheless, the Queen could still exercise any of her powers with respect to the State if she was "personally present" in the State.There is no equivalent provision as to the Commonwealth. However, for both the Commonwealth and the States, constitutional convention effectively excludes the monarch from any personal exercise of governmental power. The 1986 proclamation was an exception, approved by Australian ministers. |- | {{sort|Bahamas|{{flagicon|The Bahamas}} [[The Bahamas]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1973-07-1010 July 1973 | Caribbean | align="right" |402,576 | |- | {{sort|Bangladesh|{{flagicon|Bangladesh}} [[Bangladesh]]}} | 1972-04-1818 April 1972{{cite book|title=Secession|last=Kohen|first=Marcelo G.|year=2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=London|isbn=978-0-521-84928-9|page=122}} | Asia | align="right" |165,867,307 | Declared independence from [[Pakistan]] in 1971.{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthofnations.org/commonwealth/history|title=Wind of Change|date=2016|publisher=Commonwealth of Nations|accessdate=2016-10-15}} |- | {{sort|Barbados|{{flagicon|Barbados}} [[Barbados]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1966-11-3030 November 1966 | Caribbean | align="right" |286,618 | |- | {{sort|Belize|{{flagicon|Belize}} [[Belize]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1981-09-2121 September 1981 | North [[Brunei]]}} | 1984-01-011 January 1984 | Asia | align="right" |439,022 | |- | {{sort|Cameroon|{{flagicon|Cameroon}} [[Cameroon]]}} | 1995-11-1313 November 1995{{cite journal|last=Pondi Table]]|volume=86|issue=344|pages=563–570|doi=10.1080/00358539708454389}} | Africa | align="right" |24,836,674 | Most of the country was the formerly French [[League of Nations Mandate|mandate]] territory (later [[United Nations Trust Territories|UN trust territory]]) of [[Cameroun]] and gained independence from [[France]] on 1 January 1960, uniting with the much smaller former British mandate/trust territory of [[Southern Cameroons]] on its gaining independence from the [[United Kingdom]] on 1 October 1961. |- | {{sort|Canada|{{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canada]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | North America | align="right" |36,885,861 | Granted nominal independence ([[British Dominions|Dominion]] status) on 1 July 1867. Canada was the first among the several original Dominions at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145152/history|title=Canada – History|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418032915/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145152/history/|archivedate=18 April 2008|df=}} Incorporated another original Dominion, [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], on 31 March 1949. The ''[[Canada Act 1982]]'' formally ended the "request and consent" provisions of the Statute of Westminster 1931 in relation to Canada, whereby the British parliament had a general power to pass laws extending to Canada at its own request. |- | {{sort|Cyprus|{{flagicon|Cyprus}} [[Cyprus]]}}{{ref|5|[E]}} | 1961-03-1313 March 1961{{cite journal|last=McIntyre|first=W. David|authorlink=W. David McIntyre|date=January 2000|title=Britain and the creation of the Commonwealth Secretariat|journal=[[Journal of Imperial and Commonwealth History]]|volume=28|issue=1|pages=135–158|doi=10.1080/03086530008583082}} | Eurasia | align="right" |1,197,667 | Gained independence from the [[United Kingdom]] on 16 August 1960. |- | {{sort|Dominica|{{flagicon|Dominica}} [[Dominica]]}} | 1978-11-033 November 1978 | Caribbean | align="right" |72,975 | |- | {{sort|Eswatini|{{flagicon|Eswatini}} [[Eswatini]]}} | 1968-09-066 September 1968 | Africa | align="right" | 1,336,933 | |- |{{sort|Fiji|{{flagicon|Fiji}} [[Fiji]]{{ref|2|[B]}}}} | 1970-10-1010 October 1970 | Oceania | align="right" |909,024 | Left in 1987; rejoined in 1997; suspended on 6 June 2000;{{cite journal|last=Ingram|first=Derek|authorlink=Derek Ingram (journalist)|date=July 2000|title=Commonwealth Update|journal=[[The Round Table Journal|The Round Table]]|volume=89|issue=355|pages=311–55|doi=10.1080/00358530050083406}} suspension lifted on 20 December 2001;{{cite journal|last=Ingram|first=Derek|authorlink=Derek Ingram (journalist)|date=April 2002|title=Commonwealth Update|journal=[[The Round Table Journal|The Round Table]]|volume=91|issue=364|pages=131–59|doi=10.1080/00358530220144148}} again suspended on 8 December 2006 because of the [[2006 Fijian coup d'état]].{{cite journal|last=Ingram|first=Derek|authorlink=Derek Ingram (journalist)|date=February 2007|title=Commonwealth Update|journal=[[The Round Table Journal|The Round Table]]|volume=96|issue=388|pages=2–28|doi=10.1080/00358530701189734|last2=Soal|first2=Judith}}[http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/34580/34581/213088/010909fijisuspended.htm Fiji suspended from the Commonwealth] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429161637/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/34580/34581/213088/010909fijisuspended.htm |date=2011-04-29 }}. Commonwealth Secretariat, 1 September 2009; retrieved 11 April 2011. Suspension lifted on 26 September 2014. |- | {{sort|Gambia, The|{{flagicon|Gambia}} [[The Gambia]]}} | 1965-02-1818 February 1965 | Africa | align="right" | 2,155,958 | Withdrew on 3 October 2013 citing "[[neo-colonialism]]".{{cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/statement-commonwealth-secretary-general-kamalesh-sharma-gambia|title=Statement by Commonwealth Secretary-General Kamalesh Sharma on The Gambia|publisher=The Commonwealth|date=4 October 2013|accessdate=6 October 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/03/gambia-quits-commonwealth-yahya-jammeh|title=Gambia quits the Commonwealth|publisher=The Guardian|date=2 October 2013|accessdate= 5 October 2013}} Following the [[Gambian presidential election, 2016|election]] of [[Adama Barrow]] as President of Gambia in 2016, it submitted an application to re-join the Commonwealth on 22 January 2018,{{cite news|title=The Gambia presents formal application to re-join the Commonwealth|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/gambia-presents-formal-application-re-join-commonwealth|accessdate=24 January 2018|publisher=The Commonwealth|date=23 January 2018|format=Media Release}} and rejoined on 8 February 2018.{{cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/gambia-rejoins-commonwealth|title=The Gambia rejoins the Commonwealth|date=8 February 2018|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat}} |- | {{sort|Ghana|{{flagicon|Ghana}} [[Ghana]]}} | 1957-03-066 March 1957 | Africa | align="right" | 1965), [[Crown Colony of North Borneo|North Borneo]], and [[Crown Colony of Sarawak|Sarawak]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145165/history|title=Malaysia – The first country to be admitted to the Commonwealth without any former colonial or constitutional links with the United Kingdom. |- | {{sort|Namibia|{{flagicon|Namibia}} [[Namibia]]}} | 1990-03-2121 March 1990 | Africa | align="right" | 2,600,857 | Gained independence from [[South Africa]].[http://www.klausdierks.com/Chronology/132.htm Chronology of Namibian Independence] Includes [[Walvis Bay]] and the [[Penguin Islands]] transferred by South Africa at midnight 28 February 1994. |- | {{sort|Nauru|{{flagicon|Nauru}} [[Nauru]]{{ref|1|[B]}}}} | 1968-11-01†1 November 1968 | Oceania | align="right" | 10,387 | Gained independence on 31 January 1968 from joint trusteeship of [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[United Kingdom]]. A [[Special membership of the Commonwealth of Nations|special member]] from 1 November 1968 until 1 May 1999, when it became a full member,{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/press/31555/34582/34786/nauru_accedes_to_full_membership_of_the_commonweal.htm |title=Nauru Accedes to Full Membership of the Commonwealth |accessdate=30 January 2009 |publisher=[[Commonwealth Secretariat]] |date=12 April 1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426051802/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/press/31555/34582/34786/nauru_accedes_to_full_membership_of_the_commonweal.htm |archivedate=26 April 2009 |df= }} before reverting to special status in January 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145172/history|title=Nauru–History|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903225217/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145172/history/|archivedate=3 September 2008|df=}} A full member again since June 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=61413|title=Nauru back as full Commonwealth member|date=26 June 2011|work=[[Radio New Zealand International]]|accessdate=23 October 2011}} |- | {{sort|New Zealand|{{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[New Zealand]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | Oceania | align="right" | 4,609,755 | Granted nominal independence ([[British Dominions|Dominion]] status) on 26 September 1907. One of the original Dominions at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]], although the Statute was not adopted in New Zealand until [[Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947|1947]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145173/history|title=New Zealand – History|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080302072940/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145173/history/|archivedate=2 March 2008|df=}} Removed final links with the British Parliament in [[New Zealand Constitution Act 1986|1986]]. |- | {{sort|Nigeria|{{flagicon|Nigeria}} [[Nigeria]]}} | 1960-10-011 October 1960 | Africa | align="right" | 194,615,054 | Incorporated the former British mandate/trust territory of [[Northern Cameroons]] on 31 May 1961. Suspended in 1995, suspension lifted in 1999.{{Cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/our-member-countries/nigeria|title=Nigeria {{!}} The Commonwealth|last=|first=|date=|website=thecommonwealth.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-05}} |- | {{sort|Pakistan|{{flagicon|Pakistan}} [[Pakistan]]}} | 1947-08-1414 August 1947{{ref|3|[C]}} | Asia | align="right" | 199,031,265 | Includes the city of [[Gwadar]], transferred from [[Muscat and Oman]] on 8 September 1958. Included [[Bangladesh]] (then known as [[East Pakistan]]) until 1971. Left Commonwealth in 1972, rejoined 1989; suspended in 1999, suspension lifted in 2004; again suspended in 2007,{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/34581/172911/221107cmag.htm|title=Pakistan suspended from the Commonwealth|last=|first=|date=22 November 2007|website=|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120825155648/http://thecommonwealth.org/news/34581/172911/221107cmag.htm|archive-date=25 August 2012|dead-url=yes|accessdate=15 June 2008}} suspension lifted in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/news/34580/34581/179063/120508cmag.htm|title=Commonwealth lifts Pakistan suspension|last=|first=|date=12 May 2008|website=|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120014337/http://thecommonwealth.org/news/34580/34581/179063/120508cmag.htm|archive-date=20 January 2012|dead-url=yes|accessdate=15 June 2008}} |- | {{sort|Papua New Guinea|{{flagicon|Papua New Guinea}} [[Papua New Guinea]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1975-09-1616 September 1975 | Oceania | align="right" | 8,034,630 | Gained independence from [[Australia]]. |- | {{sort|Rwanda|{{flagicon|Rwanda}} [[Rwanda]]}} | 2009-11-2929 November 2009 | Africa | align="right" | 12,322,920 | Gained independence from [[Belgium]] on 1 July 1962. The second country (after Mozambique) to be admitted to the Commonwealth without any former colonial or constitutional links with the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/8384930.stm|title=Rwanda becomes a member of the Commonwealth|publisher=BBC News|date=29 November 2009|accessdate=29 November 2009}} Unlike Mozambique, has adopted English as an [[official language]] since joining. |- | {{sort|Saint Kitts and Nevis|{{flagicon|Saint Kitts and Nevis}} [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]]{{ref|1|[B]}}}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1983-09-1919 September 1983 | Caribbean | align="right" | 56,632 | |- | {{sort|Saint Lucia|{{flagicon|Saint Lucia}} [[Saint Lucia]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1979-02-2222 February 1979 | Caribbean | align="right" | 189,000 | |- | {{sort|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|{{flagicon|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines}} [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1979-10-2727 October 1979 | Caribbean | align="right" | 109,501 | A [[Special membership of the Commonwealth of Nations|special member]] from 27 October 1979 until 1 June 1985. |- | {{sort|Samoa|{{flagicon|Samoa}} [[Samoa]]}}{{ref|2|[B]}} | 1970-08-2828 August 1970 | Oceania | align="right" | 196,954 | Gained independence from [[New Zealand]] on 1 January 1962. Joined as Western Samoa, subsequently changing its name to Samoa on 4 July 1997.{{cite news|title=Constitution Amendment Act (No 2) 1997|url=http://www.paclii.org/ws/legis/num_act/caa21997295|accessdate=27 November 2007}} |- | {{sort|Seychelles|{{flagicon|Seychelles}} [[Seychelles]]}} | 1976-06-2929 June 1976 | Africa | align="right" | 98,248 | |- | {{sort|Sierra Leone|{{flagicon|Sierra Leone}} [[Sierra Leone]]}} | 1961-04-2727 April 1961 | Africa | align="right" | 6,818,117 | |- | {{sort|Singapore|{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Singapore]]{{ref|2|[B]}}}} | 1965-10-15†9 August 1966 (effective from 9 August 1965){{sourcetext|source=Singapore Act 1966}} | Asia | align="right" | 5,889,117 | Gained independence from the [[United Kingdom]] and joined [[Federation of Malaysia]] on 16 September 1963. Became independent on 9 August 1965.{{cite news|title=Road to Independence |publisher=AsiaOne |accessdate=28 June 2006 |url=http://ourstory.asia1.com.sg/merger/merger.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013002423/http://ourstory.asia1.com.sg/merger/merger.html |archivedate=13 October 2013 |df= }} |- | {{sort|Solomon Islands|{{flagicon|Solomon Islands}} [[Solomon Islands]]}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1978-07-077 July 1978 | Oceania | align="right" | 614,497 | |- | {{sort|South Africa|{{flagicon|South Africa}} [[South Africa]]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | Africa | align="right" | 56,007,479 | Granted nominal independence ([[British Dominions|Dominion]] status) on 31 May 1910. One of the original [[British Dominions|Dominions]] at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]]. Left on 31 May 1961; rejoined 1 June 1994.{{cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/our-member-countries/south-africa|title=South Africa|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=2016-01-25}} |- | {{sort|Sri Lanka|{{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} [[Sri Lanka]]}} | 1948-02-044 February 1948 | Asia | align="right" | 20,979,811 | Joined as the [[Dominion of Ceylon]], subsequently changing its name in 1972. Became a republic in 1972 |- | {{sort|Tanzania|{{flagicon|Tanzania}} [[Tanzania]]}} | 1961-12-099 December 1961 | Africa | align="right" | 57,790,062 | Joined as [[Tanganyika]] and later [[Zanzibar]], which subsequently merged to form [[Tanzania]] on 26 April 1964.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145193/history|title=Tanzania – History|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903225028/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145193/history/|archivedate=3 September 2008|df=}} |- | {{sort|Tonga|{{flagicon|Tonga}} [[Tonga]]}} | 1970-06-044 June 1970 | Oceania | align="right" | 107,228 | |- | {{sort|Trinidad and Tobago|{{flagicon|Trinidad and Tobago}} [[Trinidad and Tobago]]}} | 1962-08-3131 August 1962 | Caribbean | align="right" | 1,376,801 | Granted nominal independence ([[British Dominions|Dominion]] status) on 31 August 1962. Became a [[Republics in the Commonwealth of Nations|republic within the Commonwealth]] on August 1, 1976 under the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago Constitution Act 1976, passed by the Parliament of Trinidad and Tobago. |- | {{sort|Tuvalu|{{flagicon|Tuvalu}} [[Tuvalu]]{{ref|1|[B]}}}}{{ref|4|[D]}} | 1978-10-011 October 1978 | Oceania | align="right" | 10,116 | A [[Special membership of the Commonwealth of Nations|special member]] from 1 October 1978 until 1 September 2000.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/press/31555/34582/141646/tuvalu_accedes_to_full_membership_of_the_commonwea.htm|title=Tuvalu Accedes to Full Membership of the Commonwealth|accessdate=30 January 2009|publisher=[[Commonwealth Secretariat]]|date=14 August 2000|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011110022/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/press/31555/34582/141646/tuvalu_accedes_to_full_membership_of_the_commonwea.htm|archivedate=11 October 2008|df=}} |- | {{sort|Uganda|{{flagicon|Uganda}} [[Uganda]]}} | 1962-10-099 October 1962 | Africa | align="right" | 42,288,962 | |- | {{sort|United Kingdom|{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom]]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | Europe | align="right" | 65,746,853 | The Parliament of the United Kingdom enacted the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]]. |- | {{sort|Vanuatu|{{flagicon|Vanuatu}} [[Vanuatu]]{{ref|1|[B]}}}} | 1980-07-3030 July 1980 | Oceania | align="right" | 279,953 | Gained independence from joint rule of [[France]] and [[United Kingdom]]. |- | {{sort|Zambia|{{flagicon|Zambia}} [[Zambia]]}} | 1964-10-2424 October 1964 | Africa | align="right" | 17,470,471 | |} {{note|1}}A. Unless otherwise noted, independence was gained from the United Kingdom on the date (shown in column 2) of joining the Commonwealth.
{{note|2}}B. Not a member of the [[Commonwealth Foundation]].
{{note|3}}C. Though Pakistan celebrates 14 August 1947 as its independence day, independence was officially granted at midnight, 15 August 1947. Therefore, its date of joining the Commonwealth would be 15 August 1947.
{{note|4}}D. [[Commonwealth realm|Commonwealth realms]], recognising [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] as their head of state since the day of their independence, distinctly from her being the sovereign of the United Kingdom.
{{note|5}}E. Geopolitically part of [[Europe]], but geographically part of [[Asia]]. ==Former members== {| class="wikitable" ! Country ! Joined ! Continent ! Left ! width= 400px|Notes |- | {{sort|Ireland|{{flagicon|Republic of Ireland}} [[Republic of Ireland]]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | Europe | 1949-04-1818 April 1949 | One of the original [[British Dominions|Dominions]] at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]].{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthofnations.org/commonwealth/history|title=Dominion Status|publisher=Commonwealth of Nations|date=2016|accessdate=2016-10-15}} Withdrew after passing the [[Republic of Ireland Act]] in 1948, accepted by the United Kingdom in 1949 [[Ireland Act 1949]]. |- | {{sort|Maldives|{{flagicon|Maldives}} [[Maldives]]}} | 1982-07-099 July 1982 | Asia | 2016-10-1313 October 2016 | Gained independence from the [[United Kingdom]] on 26 July 1965.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145167/history|title=Maldives – History|publisher=Commonwealth Secretariat|accessdate=15 February 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705060545/http://www.thecommonwealth.org/YearbookInternal/145167/history/|archivedate=5 July 2008|df=}} A [[Special membership of the Commonwealth of Nations|special member]] from 9 July 1982 until 20 July 1985.{{Cite web|url=http://www.maldiveshighcommission.org/?id_w=8|title=The Maldives and the Commonwealth|accessdate=30 January 2009|publisher=Republic of Maldives}} Announced on 13 October 2016 that it has withdrawn from the Commonwealth.{{Cite web|url=http://thecommonwealth.org/media/news/secretary-general-statement-maldives-decision-leave-commonwealth|title=Commonwealth Secretariat|last=|first=|date=2016-10-13|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-13}}"[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/13/maldives-quits-commonwealth-over-alleged-rights-abuses Maldives quits Commonwealth over alleged rights abuses]". ''The Guardian''. 13 October 2016. ''"The Maldives has announced it will leave the Commonwealth after mounting pressure from the 53-nation group over corruption and deteriorating human rights in the Indian Ocean state. The country’s government, which has been fending off rumours of an impending coup and allegations of money laundering, said the decision on Thursday to cancel its membership was 'difficult but inevitable'. Its foreign ministry said in a statement it had been treated 'unjustly and unfairly' by the organisation’s Commonwealth ministerial action group (CMAG), which has been scrutinising the government since the former president, Mohamed Nasheed, was ousted in 2012 in what his supporters say was a coup. 'The CMAG and the Commonwealth secretariat seem to be convinced that the Maldives, because of the high and favourable reputation that the country enjoys internationally, and also perhaps because it is a small state that lacks material power, would be an easy object that can be used,' the statement said. It added that it was being targeted 'in the name of democracy promotion, to increase the [Commonwealth’s] own relevance and leverage in international politics'."'' The cabinet of [[Ibrahim Mohamed Solih]] has announced that the Maldives is to return to its status as a [[Commonwealth republic]]https://presidency.gov.mv/presidentNews/news/10346 |- | {{sort|Zimbabwe|{{flagicon|Zimbabwe}} [[Zimbabwe]]}} | 1980-10-011 October 1980 | Africa | 2003-12-077 December 2003 | Suspended on 19 March 2002. Withdrew voluntarily on 7 December 2003.{{cite journal|date=January 2004|title=Editorial: CHOGM 2003, Abuja, Nigeria|journal=[[The Round Table Journal|The Round Table]]|volume=93|issue=373|pages=3–6|doi=10.1080/0035853042000188139}} |- |} ==Dissolved members== {| class="wikitable" !Former country !Joined !Continent !Dissolved !Rejoined as part of !width=400px|Notes |- | {{sort|Malaya|{{flagicon|Malaya}} [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]]}} | 1957-08-3131 August 1957 | Asia | 1963-07-3131 July 1963 | {{sort|Malaysia|{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia]]}} | Reformed as the [[Federation of Malaysia]] with [[Singapore]] (became a separate member in 1965), [[Sabah]], and [[Sarawak]]. |- | {{sort|Newfoundland|{{flagicon|Newfoundland}} [[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]]}} | 1931-12-1111 December 1931 | North America | 1934-02-1631 March 1949 | {{sort|Canada|{{flagicon|Canada|1921}} [[Canada]]}} | One of the original [[British Dominions|Dominions]] at the time of the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]]. Government suspended on 16 February 1934, merged into [[Canada]] on 31 March 1949. |- | {{sort|Tanganyika|{{flagicon|Tanganyika}} [[Tanganyika]]}} | 1961-12-099 December 1961 | rowspan="2"|Africa | rowspan="2"|1964-04-2626 April 1964 | rowspan="2"|{{sort|Tanzania|{{flagicon|Tanzania}} [[Tanzania]]}} | rowspan="2"|The two countries merged to form [[Tanzania]] on 26 April 1964. |- | {{sort|Zanzibar|{{flagicon image|Flag_of_Zanzibar_(January-April_1964).svg}} [[Zanzibar]]}} | 1963-12-1010 December 1963 |- |} ==Prospective members== {| class="wikitable" ! Country ! Applied ! Continent ! Population !width=400px|Notes |- | {{sort|Somaliland|{{flagicon|Somaliland}} [[Somaliland]]}} | 2009[http://www.qarannews.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=6381&Itemid=59 Somaliland on verge of observer status in the Commonwealth.] ''Qaran News'', 16 November 2009 | Africa | align=right| ~3,500,000{{ref|6|[F]}} | Somaliland is an unrecognised self-declared sovereign state internationally recognised as part of [[Somalia]]. It has applied to join the Commonwealth under [[observer status]]. Its borders approximate to those of [[British Somaliland]], which was a protectorate from 1884 to 1960. |- |{{sort|Sudan|{{flagicon|Sudan}} [[Sudan]]}} | 2009{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-the-commonwealths-role-and-is-it-relevant-to-global-politics-1827478.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=Daniel | last=Howden | title=The Big Question: What is the Commonwealth's role, and is it relevant to global politics? | date=26 November 2009}} |Africa |align=right| 42,425,989 |Sudan was a condominium of the United Kingdom and Egypt known as [[Anglo-Egyptian Sudan]], but in practice the structure of the Condominium ensured full British control over the [[Sudan]] until its independence in 1956. Sudan has expressed an interest in joining the Commonwealth.{{cite web|url=http://www.cpsu.org.uk/fileadmin/Gov_and_Demo/Widening_vs_Deepening.doc |title=The future of the modern Commonwealth: Widening vs. deepening? |accessdate=16 September 2006 |date=10 October 2005 |format=doc |first=Victoria |last=te Velde-Ashworth |publisher=Commonwealth Policy Studies Unit |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723140846/http://www.cpsu.org.uk/fileadmin/Gov_and_Demo/Widening_vs_Deepening.doc |archivedate=23 July 2011 }} |- | {{sort|South Sudan|{{flagicon|South Sudan}} [[South Sudan]]}} | 2011{{cite web|url=http://www.gurtong.net/ECM/Editorial/tabid/124/ctl/ArticleView/mid/519/articleId/5418/South-Sudan-Launches-Bid-to-Join-Commonwealth.aspx|title=South Sudan Launches Bid to Join Commonwealth|work=gurtong.net}} | Africa | align=right| 13,670,642 |Gained independence from Britain as part of Sudan in 1956. Gained independence from Sudan in 2011.[http://shimronletters.blogspot.com/2011/05/south-sudan-on-track-to-join.html South Sudan on Track to Join Commonwealth.] |- | {{sort|Suriname|{{flagicon|Suriname}} [[Suriname]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/12377129-suriname-plans-to-join-the-commonwealth |title=Welcome to Allvoices |work=allvoices.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625094503/http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/12377129-suriname-plans-to-join-the-commonwealth |archivedate=2013-06-25 |df= }} | 2012 | South America | align=right| 555,934 |English colony of [[History of Suriname|Willoughbyland]] from 1650 to 1667 and controlled by the British from 1799 to 1816. Subsequently, a Dutch colony. In 2012, Suriname announced plans to join the Commonwealth{{cite web|url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2012/news/regional/06/14/suriname-eying-membership-of-commonwealth-2|title=Suriname eying membership of Commonwealth|author=Staff Writer|work=Stabroek News}} and the British government has made it a priority to provide guidance to Suriname in applying for Commonwealth membership.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/priority/strengthening-guyana-s-participation-in-the-commonwealth-and-providing-guidance-to-suriname-as-it-considers-applying-for-membership|title=Strengthening Guyana’s participation in the Commonwealth and providing guidance to Suriname as it considers applying for membership|work=www.gov.uk}} |- | {{sort|Burundi|{{flagicon|Burundi}} [[Burundi]]}}{{cite web|title=Burundi Applies to Join Commonwealth to Bolster Angolophone Ties|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-11-13/burundi-applies-to-join-commonwealth-to-bolster-angolophone-ties|website=Bloomberg.com|language=en|date=13 November 2013}} | 2013 | Africa | align=right| 10,524,117 | |- |{{sort|Zimbabwe|{{flagicon|Zimbabwe}} [[Zimbabwe]]}} | 2018{{cite news| url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/05/21/africa/zimbabwe-commonwealth-countries/index.html?no-st=1528838255 | work=CNN | first=Bukola | last=Adebayo | title=Zimbabwe applies to re-join Commonwealth, 15 years after leaving | date=21 May 2018}} |Africa |align=right| 16,150,362 |In recent years, under the presidency of [[Robert Mugabe]], Zimbabwe has dominated Commonwealth affairs, creating acrimonious splits in the organisation. Zimbabwe was suspended in 2002 for breaching the [[Harare Declaration]]. In 2003, when the Commonwealth refused to lift the suspension, Zimbabwe withdrew from the Commonwealth. Since then, the Commonwealth has played a major part in trying to end the political impasse and return Zimbabwe to a state of normality. On May 15, 2018, President Mnangagwa submitted an application to rejoin the Commonwealth |} {{note|6}}F. The population figure is based on 2014 estimates. Other states which have expressed an interest in joining the Commonwealth over the years or states which may be eligible to join the Commonwealth include [[Algeria]], [[Bahrain]], [[Cambodia]], [[Egypt]], [[Eritrea]], [[Israel]]{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1537176/Israelis-and-Palestinians-could-join-Commonwealth.html|title=Israelis and Palestinians could join Commonwealth|work=The Telegraph|date=17 December 2006}}, [[Libya]], [[Madagascar]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[United States]] and [[Yemen]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/the-big-question-what-is-the-commonwealths-role-and-is-it-relevant-to-global-politics-1827478.html|location=London|work=The Independent|first=Daniel|last=Howden|title=The Big Question: What is the Commonwealth's role, and is it relevant to global politics?|date=26 November 2009}}{{cite news | last = Osike | first = Felix | title = Rwanda membership delayed | url = http://www.sundayvision.co.ug/detail.php?mainNewsCategoryId=7&newsCategoryId=123&newsId=598876 | work = [[New Vision]] | date = 24 November 2007 | accessdate =29 November 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123172352/http://www.sundayvision.co.ug/detail.php?mainNewsCategoryId=7&newsCategoryId=123&newsId=598876|archivedate=23 January 2013}} revision.text:
'''Nicolae Culianu''' (August 28, 1832 – November 28, 1915) was a [[Moldavia]]n, later [[Romania]]n mathematician and astronomer.
A native of [[Iași]], he enrolled in the [[University of Paris]] after graduating from ''[[Academia Mihăileană]]'' in 1855, and earned his undergraduate degree in mathematics in 1860. He remained there until 1863, performing research at the [[Paris Observatory]].<ref name="ieseni">{{ro icon}} Ciprian Teodorescu, [http://bjiasi.ro/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/ACADEMICIENI-IESENI.pdf ''Academicieni ieșeni''], p. 124, at the Gheorghe Asachi Iași County library site</ref> Initially a high school teacher,<ref name="o307">Ornea, p. 307</ref> he later joined the astronomy and geodesy faculty of [[Iași University]],<ref name="ieseni"/><ref name="oc"/> where he served as dean of the sciences faculty, and from 1880 to 1898 as rector.<ref name="oc"/><ref name="d">Diaconu, pp. 129–30</ref> He was a close associate of [[Titu Maiorescu]], a member of the ''[[Junimea]]'' movement that the latter led, and involved in the educational reform movement it promoted. As such, he was among the founders of a private high school in Iași, to which he donated a group of buildings.<ref name="oc"/> While active in ''Junimea'', his renowned affability and venerable bearing earned him the nickname "Papa Culiano".<ref name="o307"/> He was elected a corresponding [[list of members of the Romanian Academy|member of the Romanian Academy]] in 1889.<ref>{{ro icon}} [http://www.acad.ro/bdar/armembriLit.php?vidT=C Membrii Academiei Române din 1866 până în prezent] at the Romanian Academy site</ref>
He helped found the Iași astronomical observatory for the use of students and teachers, and published textbooks on mathematics and geodesy.<ref name="oc"/> He was among the founders ''[[Recreații Științifice]]'', the country's first scientific periodical addressed to young people and to a generalist audience.<ref name="ieseni"/><ref name="d"/> Briefly involved in politics, he was vice president of the [[Romanian Senate]] during the fourth [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880–1918)|conservative]] government of [[Lascăr Catargiu]] (1892–1896).<ref name="ieseni"/><ref name="oc">{{ro icon}} Tereza Culianu-Petrescu, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/O-biografie*articleID_989-articles_details.html "O biografie"], ''Observator Cultural'', nr. 87, October 2001</ref>
Culianu's textbooks include an 1870 one on differential and integral calculus, the first published Romanian-language course on mathematical analysis; and ones on elementary algebra (1872), applied geometry (1874), plane and spherical trigonometry (1875), cosmography (1893), plane trigonometry (1894) and high-school cosmography (1895).<ref name="ieseni"/> He was buried in [[Eternitatea cemetery]].<ref name="b">{{ro icon}} Temistocle Bîrsan, [http://www.recreatiimatematice.ro/arhiva/miscelannea/RM12011CLIMESCU.pdf "Restaurarea mormântului lui C. Climescu, fost rector al Universității din Iași"], in ''Recreații Matematice'', nr.1/2011, pp. 3–4</ref> His great-grandson was [[Ioan Petru Culianu]].<ref name="oc"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== {{ro icon}} Olga Diaconu, [http://www.recreatiimatematice.ro/arhiva/scoli/RM22012INSTITUTE.pdf "Institutele Unite – veche școală particulară model"], in ''Recreații Matematice'', nr.2/2012, pp. 128–30 *[[Zigu Ornea]], ''T. Maiorescu și prima generație de maiorescieni: corespondență'', Editura Minerva, 1978
{{authority control}}

{{More footnotes|date=June 2015}} [[File:Donna Turca andando al bagno - Nicolay Nicolas De - 1580.jpg|thumb]] {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Nicolas de Nicolay''', Sieur d'Arfeville & de Belair, (1517–1583) of the [[Nicolay (family)]] was a French geographer.
==Biography== Born at [[la Grave]] in Oisans, in the [[Dauphiné]], he left France in 1542 to participate in the siege of [[Perpignan]] which was then held by Emperor [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] of Austria.
In 1547 he sailed to Scotland where his intervention ended the [[siege of St Andrews Castle]]. In 1548 he returned to Scotland to take away [[Mary, Queen of Scots]] from [[Dumbarton Castle]], sailing around the west coast of Ireland.<ref>E. Bonnar, 'The recovery of St. Andrews Castle in 1547, French diplomacy in the British Isles', in ''English Historical Review'', (June 1996), 578–598</ref> He travelled around Germany, Denmark, England, Sweden, Italy, Spain, Greece and Turkey and served in the armies of most of these countries. On his return to France, [[Henry II of France|Henry II]] made him Geographer Ordinary and Valet to the Chamber.
Around this time, he appears to have made a terrestrial globe that provided the model for the Oterschaden globe of c.1600.
In 1551, Henry II ordered him to follow [[Gabriel d'Aramon]], envoy and ambassador to the Grand Turk [[Suleyman the Magnificent|Suleiman the Magnificent]]. In the course of the voyage, his unofficial mission was to survey the places visited, including [[Istanbul]]. It has been suggested that one of his objectives was to spy for the French crown.<ref name=":0" />
In 1583, he died in [[Soissons]], where he was Commissioner of artillery, after a stay at the royal castle of [[Moulins, Allier|Moulins]].
== ''Quatre premiers livres des navigations'' ==
Published in 1598, [http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/rosenwald.1207 ''Quatre premiers livres des navigations''] (''Travels in Turkey)'' recorded Nicolay's observations about the Ottoman court and peoples from his 1551 mission to [[Istanbul]] on behalf of the French government. The book served as the first comprehensive survey of customs and costumes in the Ottoman world, and is hailed as one of the earliest and most accurate depictions of the Islamic world to appear in Europe.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Brafman|first=David|date=2009|title=Facing East: The Western View of Islam in Nicolas de Nicolay's "Travels in Turkey"|url=|journal=Getty Research Journal|volume=1|pages=153–160}}</ref> ''Travels in Turkey'' achieved a high level of commercial success upon its release. It was later reissued and translated for a number of different countries, including [[Italy]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]], [[England]], and [[Germany]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mukerji|first=Chandra|date=2013|title=Costume and Character in the Ottoman Empire: Dress as Social Agent in Nicolay's Navigations|url=|journal=Early modern things: objects and their histories, 1500-1800|volume=|pages=151–169|via=}}</ref> The widespread popularity of the book contributed to the proliferation of costume books throughout Europe at the end of the 16th century, and continued to influence [[Orientalism|Orientalist]] artists well into the 19th century such as [[Eugène Delacroix|Eugene Delacroix]] and [[Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres]].
''Travels in Turkey'' is divided in four books, following Nicolay's voyage to [[Istanbul]], accounts of ethnic groups and Ottoman court life, and the religious and military administration in Istanbul. Louis Danet made 60 engravings based on Nicolay's original drawings, which serve as the core of the books, and each print is followed by a caption, describing Islamic ritual, religion and monuments. The images cover all aspects of Ottoman daily life, and depict figures ranging from [[sultan]]s and sultanas to wrestlers, cooks and [[Janissaries|Janissary]] generals.<ref name=":0" /> The images are typical of costume books, and consist of lone figures, depicted on a very sparse background, which emphasizes the dress of the figure, rather than geography. In the costume book, figures are schematized and follow general types, and Brafman writes that "Nicolay, or his engravers, render facial expressions in an exaggerated style. Emotional reaction are evoked artistically, whether it be identification with a mother, sympathy for a Christian slave, or fascination with exotic and 'monstrous' alien practice".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brafman|first=David|date=2009|title=Facing East: The Western View of Islam in Nicolas de Nicolay's "Travels in Turkey"|url=|journal=Getty Research Journal|volume=1|pages=158}}</ref><gallery> File:Deli-Nicolas-de-Nicolay.jpg|Delli horseman from a 1576 Italian edition of Nicolas de Nicolay's Navigations,1567. File:Les navigations, peregrinations et voyages, faicts en la Turquie, par Nicolas de Nicolay - no-nb digibok 2013080124004-209.jpg|Peich or Lackey from a 1576 Italian edition of Nicolas de Nicolay's Navigations, 1567. File:Gli ubbriachi (Azamoglan, Levantino, Azappi) - Nicolay Nicolas De - 1580.jpg|Gli Ubbriachi File:Dervisio religioso Turco che si fa tagli p la vita - Nicolay Nicolas De - 1580.jpg|Deruisio religioso Turco che si fa tagli p[er] la vita File:Calendiero Religioso Turco che porta anella oltra l'altre parti del corpo al membro virile per farsi inhabile alcoito - Nicolay Nicolas De - 1580.jpg|Calendiero Religioso Turco che porta anella oltra l'altre parti del corpo al membro virile File:Fanciulo di Tributo creato nel Serraglio - Nicolay Nicolas De - 1580.jpg|Fanciullo di Tributo creato nel Serraglio </gallery>
==Works and maps== [[File:Houghton Typ 530.77.606 - Le navigationi et viaggi nella Turchia, Gentildonna Turca.jpg|thumb|Illustration from ''Le navigationi et viaggi nella Turchia'', 1577]] He wrote several books:
*''Description générale des Pays et Duché de Berry'' (1567). *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/rosenwald.1207 ''Quatre premiers livres des navigations''] (1568) *''Description générale du Bourbonnais en 1569, ou Histoire de cette province (villes, bourgs, châteaux, fiefs, monastères, familles anciennes'' (published in 1875). *''Description générale de la ville de Lyon et des anciennes provinces du Lyonnais et du Beaujolais'' (published in 1881). *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/rosenwald.1207 ''Discovrs et histoire veritable des navigations, Anvers, A. Coninx,' 1586.] From the [https://www.loc.gov/rr/rarebook/ Rare Book and Special Collections Division] at the [[Library of Congress]] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k853119.image.f1.langFR ''Les navigations, peregrinations et voyages faicts en la Turquie'', (Antwerp 1576)] at [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] (Gallica site) *[http://maps.nls.uk/coasts/chart.cfm?id=169 Nicolas D'Arfeville's map of Scotland] at the [[National Library of Scotland]]
== Sources == *''Voyage en Orient au XVIe siècle de Nicolas de Nicolay, Dauphinois'', par Honoré Pallias, 1857. [http://www.bibliotheque-dauphinoise.com/voyage_nicolay.html] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k35159q/f1.table] ''Description du Berry et diocèse de Bourges au XVIe siècle par Nicolas de Nicolay Dauphinois, géographe et valet de chambre du roi Charles IX [...] avec une notice sur l'auteur par M. Victor Advielle'', Paris, A. Aubry et Dumoulin, 1865. * R. Herve,"L'oeuvre cartographique de Nicolas de Nicolay et d'Antoine de Leval, 1544-1619", ''Bulletin de la Section de Géographie du Comité des Travaux Historiques et Scientifiques'' (Paris), LXVIII (1955), 223-63. *Roger Hervé, ''L'Œuvre cartographique de Nicolas de Nicolay et d'Antoine de Laval (1544–1619),'' Paris, Imprimerie nationale, 1956. *Franz Wawrik, “Der Erdglobus des Johannes Oterschaden”, ''Der Globusfreund,'' Nos.25-27, 1978, pp. 155–167.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{about|the Welsh academic|the Welsh footballer|Owain Tudur Jones|another Welsh footballer of the same name|Owain Jones (footballer)}} {{Multiple issues| {{autobiography|date=November 2010}} {{cleanup|date=November 2010}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2010}} }} '''Owain Jones''' [[Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society|FGS]] (born 1957, [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], Wales) is a Professor of Environmental Humanities at [[Bath Spa University]] (UK). He was previously [[Reader (academic rank)|Reader]] in Cultural Geography: Place, Nature and Landscape (previously Senior Research Fellow) at the Countryside & Community Research Institute (which is a joint Institute of the Universities of the [[West of England University|West of England]] and [[University of Gloucestershire|Gloucestershire]] and the [[Royal Agricultural College]] and [[Hartpury College]]) and member of staff of the Department of Geography and Environmental Management, Faculty of Environment and Technology, University of the West of England.
He works mainly in [[cultural geography]] and has published a number of peer-reviewed research articles in international [[geography]] and related [[social science]] journals. He has two main areas of research and writing interests; geographies of nature-culture and [[children's geographies]]. Within the former he focuses upon [[animal geographies]],<ref>Jones O., (2008) '"The Restraint of Beasts": rurality, animality, actor network theory and dwelling', in P. Cloke (ed.) Country Visions, London: [[Pearson Education]]. pp 450–487.</ref> [[place (geography)|place]]/[[landscape]]/[[dwelling]],<ref>Jones O., (2006) ''Of Trees and Trails: place in a globalised world'', in N. Clark, D. Massey, and P. Sarre (eds.) Life in A Globalised World, Milton Keynes: Open University, pp 214–264.</ref> and [[tidal]] geographies (and temporal rhythms of landscape).<ref>Jones O., (2010)''The Breath of the Moon': The Rhythmic and Affective Time-spaces of UK Tides'', in T. Edensor (ed) Geographies of Rhythm, Oxford: [[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate]], pp 189–203.</ref>
== Biography == Jones undertook a BA in 3D Design/Construction at [[Bristol Polytechnic]], graduating in 1981, an MA /Postgraduate Diploma in Environmental Policy and Geography, [[University of the West of England]], 1993, MSc. in Society and Space, [[University of Bristol]], 1993, MA in Creative Writing, BSUC, 2004 and completed his PhD in the Dept of Geography, [[University of Bristol]] in 1997. He has conducted research variously funded by the [[ESRC]], [[Arts and Humanities Research Council|AHRC]], and [[RCUK]] (RELU). He has also written on geography, [[non-representational theory]] and pragmatism.<ref>Jones O., (2008) 'Stepping from the Wreckage: Non-representational theory and the promise of pragmatism’ in special issue on Pragmatism and Geography, [[Geoforum]], edited by N. Wood and S. Smith, Geoforum, 39, 1600–1612</ref> and geography and memory.<ref>Jones O., (2005) 'An Emotional Ecology of Memory, Self and Landscape', in J. Davidson, L. Bondi and M. Smith (eds.) Emotional Geographies, Oxford, [[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate]], pp 205–218.</ref>
His work is of significance in the area of geographies nature-culture. That is – a view of nature-society relations which seeks to understand the interdependency between the human and non-human world. This draws upon, and contributes to, a range of theories including Actor Network Theory (ANT);<ref>[[Bruno Latour]] (1993) ''We Have Never Been Modern''. Hemel Hempstead: Harvester/Wheatsheaf.</ref> [[dwelling]];<ref>[[Tim Ingold]] (2000). ''The Perception of the Environment. Essays in Livelihood, Dwelling and Skill''. London: Routledge.</ref> [[hybridity]];<ref>Whatmore, S. (2002). Hybrid Geographies: Natures, Cultures, Spaces. London: Sage.</ref> new [[dialectics]];<ref>Bruce Braun, (2006). ''Towards a new earth and a new humanity: nature, ontology, politics'', In N. Castree and D. Gregory (eds), [[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]]. A Critical Reader. Oxford: Blackwell Publishing, pp. 191–222.</ref> new approaches to place;<ref>[[Doreen Massey (geographer)|Doreen Massey]](2005). ''For Space''. London: Sage. {{ISBN|1412903610}}.</ref> and new ecologies.
The importance of his work is reflected in the selection of an extract from the book "''Tree Cultures: The Place of Trees, and Trees in their Place'',<ref>Jones O., and Cloke P., (2002) ''Tree Cultures: The Place of Trees, and Trees in their Place'', Oxford: Berg, 252pp.</ref> for the “Nature” section of ''The Cultural Geography Reader'' edited by Oakes and Price.<ref>T. S. Oakes and P. L. Price (eds) ''The Cultural Geography Reader'', London: Routledge.</ref> This extract sits alongside other seminal writings on nature by [[Raymond Williams]], [[Clarence J. Glacken]], [[Alexander Wilson (ornithologist)|Alexander Wilson]] and others. Because of his work in this field, Owain Jones was selected to write the "Nature-Culture"<ref>Jones O. (2008). ''Nature-Cultures'' in R. Kitchen and N. Thrift (eds.), ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography'', London: [[Elsevier]], vol 7: 309–323.</ref> and "Dwelling"<ref>Jones O., 2008 ''Dwelling'' in R. Kitchen and N. Thrift (eds.), ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography'', London: [[Elsevier]], vol 3: 266–272.</ref> entries for the ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography''.<ref>R. Kitchen and N. Thrift (eds.) (2009). ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography'', London: [[Elsevier]].</ref>
Owain Jones's influential 1995 paper on discourses of [[rurality]]<ref>Jones O., (1995) "Lay Discourses of the Rural: Developments and Implications for Rural Studies", ''Journal of Rural Studies'', 11, 1, pp 35–49.</ref> has been recently republished as part of the ''Journal of Rural Studies''' 25th anniversary.<ref>http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/S06_343.cws_home/vsijrurstud_rurality </ref>
He has also been an invited speaker at a number of major international academic conferences on rurality,<ref>http://www.campoadentro.es/en/conferencia_internacional</ref> [[human-animal interactions]],<ref>http://www.uio.no/forskning/tverrfak/kultrans/aktuelt/konferanser/sentient-creatures/</ref> and geographies of forests, places and landscapes.<ref>http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/INFD-7RXCB4</ref>
In the area of children's geographies Owain Jones has pioneered the idea of the "otherness of children".<ref>Jones O., (2008) “True geography [ ] quickly forgotten, giving away to an adult-imagined universe. Approaching the otherness of childhood". ''Children's Geographies'', 8, 2, pp 195–212..</ref> This has been taken up by other academics such as Karen Lury.<ref>Karen Lury (2010) ''The Child in Film''. I. B. Tarus.</ref>
Owain Jones is also founder and Chair of Priston Festival, a community art and music festival near the city of [[Bath, Somerset]], south west England.
== Current academic positions and affiliations == * Chair of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] Research Group on Children, Youth and Families * Committee member of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] Cultural and Social Geography Research Group * Associate Editor of the journal of Children's Geographies. * Associate member of Land2 (a UK based practice-led research network of artists and academics with interests in landscape / place-oriented art practice). * Fellow of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] and Research Group committee member
== Recent publications by year since 2000 == * Book. Jones O., and Cloke P., (2002) ''Tree Cultures: The Place of Trees, and Trees in their Place'', Oxford: Berg, 252pp. * Val Steeves and Owain Jones (2010) Editorial: Surveillance and Children. Surveillance & Society 7(3/4): 187–191. * Jones O., ‘The Breath of the Moon’: The Rhythmic and Affective Time-spaces of UK Tides, in T. Edensor (ed) Geographies of Rhythm, Oxford: [[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate]], pp 189–203. * Jones O., 'Dwelling' in R. Kitchen and N. Thrift (eds.), ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography'', London: [[Elsevier]], vol 3: 266–272. * Jones O., 'Nature-Cultures' in R. Kitchen and N. Thrift (eds.), ''International Encyclopaedia of Human Geography'', London: [[Elsevier]], vol 7: 309–323. * Jones O., 'After Nature: Entangled Worlds’ in N. Castree, D. Demeritt, D. Liverman and B. Rhoads, (eds.), A Companion to Environmental Geography Oxford: [[Wiley-Blackwell|Blackwell]] Publishing pp 294–312. * Jones O. 'Approaching the otherness of childhood; methodological considerations', in Van Blerk, L. and Kesby, M. (eds) Doing Children's Geographies: Methodological Issues in Research with Young People, London: Routledge, pp 195–212. * Jones O., and Cloke P., ‘Orchard’ in T. S. Oakes and P. L. Price (eds) ''The Cultural Geography Reader'', London: Routledge, pp 232–240. * Jones O., and Cloke P., ‘Non-human agencies: tree is place and time’, in C. Knappett and L. Malafouris, (eds.) Material Agency: towards a non-anthropocentric approach, Guilford: [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]. pp 79–96. * Jones O., 'Of Trees and Trails: place in a globalised world’, in N. Clark, D. Massey, and P. Sarre (eds.) Material Geographies: A World in the Making, London: [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] in association with the [[Open University]], pp 214–264. * Jones O., '"True geography [ ] quickly forgotten, giving away to an adult-imagined universe". Approaching the otherness of childhood'. Children's Geographies, 8, 2, pp 195–212. * Jones O., 'Stepping from the Wreckage: Non-representational theory and the promise of pragmatism’ in special issue on Pragmatism and Geography, [[Geoforum]], edited by N. Wood and S. Smith, Geoforum, 39, 1600–1612. * Brown B., Laurier E,. Lorimer H,. Jones O., Juhlin O., Noble A., Perry M., Pica D., Sormani. P., Strebel I., Swan L., Taylor A., Watts L. and Weilenmann A., 'Driving and passengering: notes on the natural organisation of ordinary car travel’ Mobilities, Volume 3, Issue 1, pp 1 – 23. * Jones O., ‘Loudon’s orders: Arnos Vale cemetery and the lively materialities of place’, in the Journal of Garden History, special issue on Arboretum edited by S. Daniels, C. Watkins and P. Elliot, pp 149–171. * Jones O., ‘Rurality and the Otherness of Childhood in a British context’ in R. Panelli, S. Punch and E. Robson (eds.) Young Rural Lives: global perspectives on rural childhood and youth, London, [[Routledge]], pp 193–204. * Jones O., 'Idylls and Othernesses: Depictions of Rural Childhood in Film’, in R. Fish (ed.) Cinematic Countrysides, Manchester, [[Manchester University Press]], pp 177–194. * Jones O., 'Of Trees and Trails: place in a globalised world’, in N. Clark, D. Massey, and P. Sarre (eds.) Life in A Globalised World, Milton Keynes: Open University, pp 214–264. * Williams, M., Jones, O., Wood, L., and Fleuriot, C., ‘Investigating New Wireless Technologies and their Potential Impact on Children’s Spatiality: A role for GIS’, Transactions in GIS, 10 (1), pp 87–102. * Jones O., ‘Non Human Rural Studies’ in P. Cloke, T. Marsden and P. Mooney, (eds.) Handbook of Rural Studies, London: [[SAGE Publications|Sage]], pp 185–200. * Sarre P., Jones, O., Meegan, J., and Brook, C. Learning Companion 3: Living in a Globalised World, Milton Keynes: [[Open University]]. * Jones O., 'An Emotional Ecology of Memory, Self and Landscape', in J. Davidson, L. Bondi and M. Smith (eds.) Emotional Geographies, Oxford, [[Ashgate Publishing|Ashgate]], pp 205–218. * Cloke, P., and Jones O., '"Unclaimed Territory": Childhood and Disordered Spaces(s)', Social and Cultural Geography, 6, 3, pp 311–323. * Cloke, P., and Jones, O., 'Turning in the Graveyard: trees and the hybrid geographies of dwelling, monitoring and resistance in a Bristol Cemetery’, Cultural Geography, 11, 3, pp 313–341. * Jones O., ‘Places of Trees’, Trees, Journal of the International Tree Foundation, Vol 64, pp 18–19. * Jones O., ‘Chris Philo: Neglected Rural Geographies, 1992’ in J. McKendrick (ed.) First Steps: A Primer on the Geographies of Children, Youth and Families. London: Limited Life Working Party on Children, Youth and Families of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] with the Institute of British Geographers, p 8. * Jones O., '"The Restraint of Beasts": rurality, animality, actor network theory and dwelling', in P. Cloke (ed.) Country Visions, London: [[Pearson Education]]. pp 450–487. * Cloke, P. and Jones, O, 'Grounding Ethical Mindfulness For / In Nature: Trees In Their Places’, Ethics, Place and Environment, 6, 3, pp 195–213. * Jones O., Williams, M. and Fleuriot C. ‘A New Sense of Place?’ Mobile, ‘Wearable’ ICT Devices and the Geographies of Urban Childhood’, Children’s Geographies, 1, 2, pp 165–180. * Jones O., ‘“Endlessly Revisited and Forever Gone”: on memory and emotional imaginations in doing children’s geographies. An ‘Addendum’ to ‘“To Go Back up the Side Hill”: Memories, Imaginations and Reveries of Childhood’ by Chris Philo, Children’s Geographies, 1, 1, pp 25–36. * Jones O., ‘Naturally Not! Childhood, the Urban and Romanticism’, Human Ecology Review, 9, 2, pp 17–30. * Morris, W., Facer, K., C. Fleuriot., Jones, O., Reid, J., and Hull, R. ‘Mobile Bristol: A New Sense of Place’ in P. Ljungstrand and L. E. Holmquist (eds.) Ubicomp2002, Adjunct Proceedings, Gotëborg, Viktoria Inst, pp 27–29. * Cloke, P., and Jones, O., ‘Dwelling, place, and landscape: an orchard in Somerset’, Environment and Planning A, 33, pp 649–66. * Little J., and Jones O., ‘Masculinity, Gender and Rural Policy’, [[Rural Sociology]], 65, 4, pp 621–639. * Jones O., '"Before the dark of reason": some ethical and epistemological considerations on the otherness of childhood', Ethics, Place and Environment, 4, 2, pp 173–178. * Jones O., 'Melting Geography: Purity, Disorder, Childhood and Space’, in S. Holloway and G. Valentine (eds.) Children’s Geographies: playing, living, learning London: [[Routledge]], pp 28–47. * Jones O., 'Inhuman Geographies: (un)Ethical Spaces of Human Non-Human Relations’, in C. Philo and C. Wilbert (eds.) Animal Spaces, Beastly Places: New Geographies of Human-Animal Relations, London: [[Routledge]], pp 268–291. * Jones O. and Little, J., 'Rural Challenge(s) Partnership and New Rural Governance', Journal of Rural Studies, 16, pp 171–18

revision.comment: new key for [[Category:Regions of West Africa by country]]: "Cape Verde" using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''[[Cape Verde]]''' is an [[archipelago]], and its islands are historically divided into two groups, or '''regions''':
* [[Barlavento Islands|Barlavento]] (meaning literally [[Windward]]), including [[Santo Antão, Cape Verde|Santo Antão]], [[São Vicente, Cape Verde|São Vicente]], [[Santa Luzia, Cape Verde|Santa Luzia]], [[São Nicolau, Cape Verde|São Nicolau]], [[Sal, Cape Verde|Sal]] and [[Boa Vista, Cape Verde|Boa Vista]], in the northern side. * [[Sotavento Islands|Sotavento]] (meaning literally [[Leeward]]), including [[Maio, Cape Verde|Maio]], [[Santiago, Cape Verde|Santiago]], [[Fogo, Cape Verde|Fogo]] and [[Brava, Cape Verde|Brava]], in the southern side.
In addition to the historical regions, the islands can also be divided by geographical features, resulting in: * A group of dry, very flat, and geologically old islands (Sal, Boa Vista and Maio), lying to the east and closer to the African coast (which makes them a target for sand from the [[Sahara desert]], resulting in long sandy beaches, typically used for beach tourism), and * A group of rocky, volcanic, agricultural islands more to the west. Their [[orography]] is rougher because they're geologically newer, and the westernmost islands (such as Santo Antão) tend to be the most mountainous.
[[Category:Geography of Cape Verde]] [[Category:Regions of West Africa by country|Cape Verde]]
